awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Advanced Materials for Energy and Sensing Applications at the University of Tennessee
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Tennessee-Knoxville entitled "Advanced Materials for Energy and Sensing Applications at the University of Tennessee" that is led by Professors Michael D. Best and Shawn R. Campagna. The site offers an intensive introductory research experience for undergraduate students which is designed to introduce and train participants in modern research techniques and also mentor them in the development of complementary professional skills that are critical for successful scientific careers. In this way, the program strengthens the scientific enterprise in the United States by recruiting students and developing them into skilled researchers at an early point in their education. Further, the program emphasizes the inclusion of a diverse group of participants to address the underrepresentation of various demographic groups in the sciences.

In this program, participating students have the opportunity to choose from a wide range of research projects that revolve around the common theme of advanced materials for energy and sensing applications. This allows students to contribute to important cutting-edge research projects that have a positive impact on the general public while simultaneously advancing their scientific training. The broader impacts of this project include the development of a well-trained and diverse set of talented students primed for future contributions to research as well as the publicizing of the achievements of participating students through the efforts of a journalist who is embedded within the program.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to provide an intensive summer undergraduate research experience to prepare participating students to be successful in graduate school and future scientific careers by developing a range of relevant skill sets. In addition to the research experience, the program also included training in comprehensive skills that are important for early scientists including ethics, modern research topics, and scientific communication. A primary objective of the program was to recruit outstanding young scientists into scientific careers, and particularly focus on those students who have limited access to research opportunities at their home institutions as well as students from under-represented minority groups. Through this funding, we were able to provide intensive training opportunities for a diverse group of 30 exceptional undergraduates.

REU students engaged in wide-ranging research that, while focused on our central theme of novel materials for energy and sensing, nevertheless involved all five traditional chemistry divisions within our department (Analytical, Inorganic, Organic, Physical, and Polymer divisions). Students received specific laboratory training related to their desired research field along with departmental equipment including Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) and mass spectrometers. Students were taken on site visits to nearby Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) and Eastman Chemical to observe chemical research in both the government and industrial sectors (except in cases where there were travel restrictions due to the COVID-19 pandemic). In addition, students received general training in safety, professional ethics, weekly seminars by chemistry faculty, and science communication.

Communication skills were enhanced through a strategic collaboration with the English Department at the University of Tennessee. Through this partnership, faculty led several workshops for our REU students designed to enhance the specific skills of CV and resume writing, as well as the preparation and presentation of scientific posters and oral talks. Faculty partners provided workshops indicating best practices and assisted students by reviewing drafts of their documents. These faculty also attended practice talks given by REU students and provided tips for enhancing their presentations.  A unique aspect of this program was the inclusion of an embedded science writer who prepared articles about each REU student for publication in their local and school newspapers. This was done to celebrate the accomplishments of our students and to publicize the program to unique audiences. A final symposium was held in which each student gave an oral presentation on the research they performed over the summer to faculty, graduate students and colleagues at Tennessee Chemistry. Overall, this program was carefully designed to advance the preparation of talented undergraduates for careers in scientific research.
